add your account a second time as IMAP. (I am assuming it is POP now) Do not remove of delete anything.

Allow the server messages to synchronize to Thunderbird. Then drag your selected messages from the IMAP folder to the appropriate location in Thunderbird. Once you have done that you can remove the IMAP mail account from Thunderbird.

There is also a standard Thunderbird page that loads when the application starts. It to contains a reference to donation, but also contains information about Thunderbird and support.

content:
I would suggest you look at the frequency of connections.

Historically Thunderbird approaches connecting to get mail as a sequential thing, so five accounts would be connected one after the other. Now it is a multi threaded thing where all five may attempt to connect at once.

I have no idea if this will help, but it might.

Stretch out the frequency of connection as far as you feel you can. Stagger the frequency 15 minutes for one account 17 for another so they all do not click over at the same time. Keep in mind that hotmail used to refuse connections that arrived at less than 15 minute frequency. so do not set account to a lesser time.

If you are using IMAP accounts try changing the connections in server settings > advance to 1 or 2. It will slow the download, but it might reduce the errors as well.

If you are not using oauth authentication, consider using it. Microsoft are in the process of enforcing it, (slowly), and if they have not got to you yet, you will only be ahead of the game.

Consider dropping email scanning if your antivirus product offers it. Some A/V product struggle to multitask on multiple mail connections at the same time. I think anyway. I know I do not have the issue and use Microsoft Defender which has no mail scanner.

content:
This is de jure in Google and Hotmail as those providers add the outgoing message to the sent folder as it passes through their server. As they do not offer an opt-out option for their bit of helpfulness and as Thunderbird defaults to making a copy, just about everyone gets two copies in the send folder.

It is a simple thing to turn of the making of sent mail copies in the copies and folders part of account settings by deselecting the place a copy in check mark.

What actually surprises me is how few people ask this question. There are other settings that get more questions asked that I see as easier to find. So I am left wondering of a significant percentage of folk are just putting up with two copies of everything.

OK, I've found the answer myself through experimentation. One webpage I found said "Right click on the account name and click on 'Settings'. An additional tab entitled 'Account Settings' will appear, select the 'Outgoing Server (SMTP)' left-hand menu option." This is what I call a "lie". What actually happens is that a new tab opens on the RHS and if you scroll down RIGHT TO THE BOTTOM you will find the SMTP details hidden away where nobody would look for them.

Frankly, I think the idea of a default SMTP server is ridiculous, since the security settings for the incoming servers might all be different, but what do I know?

Je pravdepodobné, že máte narušený profil Thunderbirdu. Vytvorte si NOVÝ PROFIL. Na vytvorenie nového profilu môžete použiť príkazy v ponuke Štart (WIN+R) a tu vypíšte: "thunderbird -p" - bez úvodzoviek a preverte, či problém pretrváva. Ak problém nepominie, tak sa môžete vrátiť k pôvodnému profilu tiež príkazom "thunderbird -p" http://imgbank.cz/images/2015/08/20/Thunderbird_novy_profil.jpg

Do NOVÉHO PROFILU si potom cez "Nástroje“ - „Importovať" - „Importovať z inej inštalácie Thunderbirdu“ importujte všetky účty a nastavenia, adresáre, e-mailové správy a kalendár ... zo STARÉHO profilu Thunderbirdu - zvolte si iba to čo potrebujete. https://imgbank.cz/images/2023/10/25/Thunderbird_import.jpg

Ak je problém odstránený, potom pokračujte v tvorbe (budovaní) NOVÉHO PROFILU Thunderbirdu. Nakoniec môžete ten STARÝ profil odstrániť.
